results.content:
I enjoyed this course a lot ! I think this is a challenging course if you are not experienced with JavaScript much but I do recommend this course if you are an experienced JavaScript engineer!

It was easy to follow for me because (1) the video materials are well edited, (2) the instructors voice is very clear and easy to understand for even non native english speakers like me (3) I have a good amount of experiences with react and redux.

I wish this course were for experienced JavaScript front engineer, so the instructor didn't need to spend time explaining the basics of HTML, CSS and JavaScript and could spend more time on the main theme of this course, that is functional programming.

results.content:
If you are beginning your adventure with programming and have chosen JavaScript as your weapon, this course is where you should begin your *serious* learning, once you're past the core basics of the language. Courses that promise you can go from 'zero to hero' as a programmer are simply lying to you. There's just too much there to ingest. On the other hand THIS is exceptional and succinct and covers just one area. And covers it in a way that leaves you with understanding (but don't mistake understanding with fluency!).

I have taken a number of courses, including a bunch of them here on Udemy. Functional Programming for Beginners is an excellent entry point into not just programming but also architecting your apps. Sure, learn the data structures and algorithms or design patterns, but it is functional programming that really brings all the other knowledge together. The apps that I built whilst following James on-screen are not complicated in terms of functionality. However, they do show how you can stitch together all the different components of your app to make it reactive and deliver the intended functionality.
I have realized how much time I've wasted on other courses that teach React, Redux, Vue or whatever other frameworks/libraries you may have out there.
James Moore is a great teacher and if it matters to anybody, he's got a very pleasant voice, speaks clearly and legibly (which isn't always the case). The course is perfectly paced if you want to stretch your knowledge. 
Oh, and it's not a 3-hour course. It took me about a full week to complete it, but this included struggling to make the assignments. Well worth it and strongly recommended!

results.content:
As a young web application developer, I am striving to learn best practices and functional-style programming. I want to learn functional programming and follow an FP style as much as possible, while staying as close to pure javascript as much as possible, especially as I learn more about web development techniques. This course fit exactly into my educational needs, as it taught me how to use JavaScript in a Functional way.

James is very thorough, starting with the most basic building blocks and expanding on them. This is my favorite teaching method, as it makes the student aware of the problems before showing solutions, rather than teaching "rules" to follow without an explanation of why they are important.

As a Node/JS developer with several years of programming under my belt, the beginning of the course seemed very slow and monotonous as James explained basic Javascript and HTML concepts that I am very familiar with. Once we started the discussions of FP practices, however, I appreciated the thorough and steady pace he set.

I would absolutely recommend this tutorial to my peers. Thanks for an excellent course, James Moore!

results.content: I enjoyed this course. It is definitely geared towards beginners. If you already understand pure functions, side-effects, composition, and currying you should probably look for a more advanced course. The mini-projects demonstrate these concepts in a more concrete way. I have not seen that done in other functional programming courses. The author does not use a framework but does use a number of helper libraries in order to reduce grunt work. RamdaJs is used throughout the course which is great since it is my favorite functional helper library.

results.content: I felt that this course was a very nice introduction to functional programming and especially web development. As was intended, the repeating of the steps used in building the 5 apps really did make the process much faster and the idea of programming apps from scratch became a natural process. I do say though that I feel as if most of the time in the course is spent on building UIs and only the first half of the course really goes into functional programming. In some of the example solutions, functions were used that someone who was functional programming beginner would not have known existed. It would been nice to have these functions explained or even practiced after their implementation, so as to get people to begin to think about using them naturally. All in all the course managed to do what it advertises and I can highly recommend it.

As was intended, the repeating of the steps used in building the 5 apps really did make the process much faster and the idea of programming apps from scratch became a natural process. I do say though that I feel as if most of the time in the course is spent on building UIs and only the first half of the course really goes into functional programming. In some of the example solutions, functions were used that someone who was functional programming beginner would not have known existed. It would been nice to have these functions explained or even practiced after their implementation, so as to get people to begin to think about using them naturally. All in all the course managed to do what it advertises and I can highly recommend it.

results.content:
The author promised a "bottom up" approach with only a few helper libraries, yet the two main libraries used (ramda and hyperscript) are the equivalent of using jQuery in a vanilla javascript course. I think that the course should be called "Functional programming with Ramda and Hyperscript". To me, that's really a bummer.
Being 50% through, I also feel that there was a lot of wasted time with "emotional" talk, and the introduction to js and css doesn't even belong into this course. 
Sections three and four are pretty good, but with the introduction of the mentioned libraries in the section 5 exercise the course becomes basically useless to me.
Btw, Hyperscript and Hyperscript-Helpers have last been updated 4 years ago and Ramda is an extremely slow project which has not even reached version one after seven years of development. Not something I would want to use in a production environment.
Then there's the part where he explains declarative programming with jQuery. Not that I am a friend of jQuery, but this is the worst example I have ever seen. Who in the world would use jQuery to hard-code a table? It is completely misleading and just meant to show everyone how bad jQuery is.
Someone else mentioned that the course is a good supplement to functional programming knowledge. That's possible, but I was expecting a vanilla js beginner functional programming class that spends most time on explaining and demonstrating the essential and difficult parts.

results.content:
This class challenged me to re-think my way of programming in JavaScript. It wasn't an easy class, and it's certainly not meant to be taken lightly. 
I had to re-read MDN documentation and do mini-projects on the side just to keep pace with the material. And it's not because the course was taught at a rapid pace, or the instructor wasn't clear in his teaching- it's just that functional programming is hard stuff. 
That said, James is methodical in his approach to teaching, as each of the projects builds on an important concept from the lecture. We start small, and then finish with a real-world application by using strictly functional-programming techniques.
I appreciate that James provides support outside of the class (i.e. slack, office-hours), and that he doesn't "hold hands" all the way, thereby allowing us to learn from our mistakes on our own. 
This class is worth it if you want to think differently and level-up your coding chops.

results.content:
I found this to be a very helpful, challenging introduction to functional programming in JavaScript. The instructor does an excellent job of motivating the main presuppositions of the functional programming paradigm, and the course also contains a satisfying amount of repetition. After working on the third and fourth apps, I felt pretty comfortable implementing a functional architecture for managing state and updating the DOM. 
If I have a criticism, it is that the instructor's explanations can sometimes be _too_ short and sweet; the expectation is that you will spend time poring over the instructor's code on your own, and while studying other people's code is a very good thing for a programmer to learn to do (no arguments there), I sometimes felt that a more patient and probing explanation would help me to digest that code better and faster.  For example, the complete account of how to implement server side effects in the final app is run through in about 3 minutes or so and it is, well, hella confusing. There is simply a lot going on there, and it would be useful to slow the pace down a little bit, and, if possible, walk through the subsequent implementation in a more piecemeal fashion to show how all of the pieces work together.

Overall, I would say that this course gives a good first taste of functional programming for web applications, and it will change the way that you code. I'm not sure that you can say much better of a short course like this.

Al principio parece muy básico, por lo menos para alguien con bastante tiempo de experiencia en software. Sin embargo, después introduce en conceptos de programación funcional de forma muy clara y a partir de ejemplos.
Me gustaría aclarar que el uso de JQuery como ejemplo de programación imperativa es un poco tendencioso, se puede trabajar de forma más ordenada y teniendo un modelo de datos, pero se entiende el concepto. De todas formas, también desaconsejo el uso de JQuery sobre todo porque hay herramientas más nuevas y poderosas.
Me parece bueno el curso. Esperaba algo más de teoría de programación funcional. Lo que está bueno es que aprendí a manejar con mayor soltura algunas cosas de javascript.

results.content:
James is a very responsive instructor with great JavaScript knowledge. His teaching methodology is awesome. He is very quick to answer questions until he makes sure you understand. He has a thing for the teaching. 

Only downside for the course is he uses third-party libraries out of nowhere such as Ramda (well-known functional library) and other hypertext libraries. This course would be perfect if he just teaches with vanilla java script. 

Other than this, the course is designed just perfect. This course is perfect for people who have intermediate JavaScript knowledge, definitely not for BEGINNERS. 
Beginners will get stuck at the projects section where James using closure, hoisting and partial functions etc. 

I will be looking forward to following other courses if creates new ones. 

Thank you James for designing this course, this course is a must for intermediate developers who want to learn Functional Programming.

results.content:
Its a great topic to do a 5 star course about. But these are the drawbacks I found about this course when comparing it to other amazing courses given on Udemy.

-2 stars for the Q&A of the course. Rather than trying to answer questions the instructor tries ways to discourage questions by being judgemental and prejudiced labeling them as confrontational, confusing or replies in a snarky tone so nobody will ask further questions. Why do they call it "tutorial" if they perceive questions from students as a threat to their authority? It might be a good tactic in after sales support to avoid work but why make a training course on such a good topic if you cant face questions ?
-1 for inconsistencies in the course. Compared to other courses there are no updates or fixes. Write once and run forever ?
-1 star for the organization of the course and for not including any Resources for the course. Never have seen anyone embedding links in videos which when typed gets redirected to load a JSBin. Why not give the link to the JSBin in the course resources directly ? It feels fishy not to include direct links for practice content in course resources like all other course instructors do on Udemy.

Pros: The instructor has good pacing and I was able to get a better understanding of how React and Redux works. You get complete git repo with starter folders and complete code.

Cons: During the last 2-3 projects, the instructor doesn't explain provide walk throughs like the first project. He expects you to figure it out and study his code. If he kept up the walk throughs, I would have given this course 5 stars.

The problem with the 'figure it out by yourself' approach is that, you don't learn by repetition of how to approach a project. You end up learning sloppy habits and waste time. For some reason this is really popular in teaching programming unlike every other discipline I have learned.

results.content:
When I first came across this course I was encouraged by the high rating, good number of apps/projects we will build, and the intro suggested a polished effort from the instructor.

The most surprising thing for me was that although the course is only 5 hours or so long, I actually spent about 30 hours to complete it. The reason for this is that the course contains a very practice oriented teaching style where each new concept is posed as a coding challenge (which can take significant time to complete to the standard of the example solution).

I really want to thank James for the effort he has put into this course. I particularly like that he uses motion graphics which would have been painstaking to create at the time, as this really helps to visually intuit what is going on in the code.

The projects are laid out carefully with each one reusing elements of previous and in there own way solving a different problem. James takes a systematic approach with spaced repetition in his teaching style and the projects section helps reinforce everything learned so far. I attempted all projects and coding challenges and found my solutions were very different from the model solutions at times. This was actually a good thing, since reviewing the model solutions and refactoring my code has really made me feel like I am learning.

I am basically totally sold on functional programming as the way forward for me in the future. James mentions he has been a professional programmer for 18 years and how functional programming has been the most impact-full discovery. As a beginner I am truly glad to have found this little gem at the beginning of my career. 

Well done James!

results.content:
Horrible Course on Functional Programming with JS.

The instructor starts off well. You cover some super basic concepts that you probably already know. All of a sudden the projects sections begin. The course becomes overwhelmingly convoluted. 80% of your attention and effort is simply trying to keep the filler code for the projects in your head so you can follow. You rarely learn anything about Ramda. 

You don't learn about Monoids, Monads, Functors, etc. None of that. The next time you go to an interview and they ask you about functional programming, you're going to be like "Well I used pipe to format a currency string and I mapped over an array to sum up all the numbers, does that count?".

He wastes an obscene amount of time covering hyperscript (a HTML generating library) and Tachyos (an offbrand knockoff version of Bootstrap 4).

He's going to show you compose(), pipe(), curry(), defaultTo(), pathFor(), map(), reduce(), filter(), find(). Instead of watching this course, you could just go look those functions up on Ramda's documentation.

I was so frustrated trying to just follow the stupid projects because he writes so much code and it's just not relevant to our learning experience.

Don't buy this course. Save your money, go to FrontEnd masters, and watch Kyle Simpson's "Functional-Lite Javascript".

results.content: The functional approach towards building the DOM model is far too over-engineered. A simpler template mechanism would be sufficient. Also, the way jQuery was presented was the worst possible approach to utilize this library. The jQuery selectors and DOM manipulation methods allow the developer to do the same thing that was presented in the course in a much more efficient and readable form.

results.content:
The preamble of the course is that functional programming is a philosophy, not a framework. We get quick examples of functional programming patterns for about 30 minutes before we're directed to a bunch of Libraries. Ramda & HyperScript specifically.

On the plus side, I got to learn about cool libraries. Ramda, HyperScript, Tachyons are all neat and interesting to work with.

Generally speaking there's not enough time practicing, explaining and breaking down functional programming patterns with just JavaScript.

There's also not a lot of time spent using functional JS in scenarios that don't involve building a reactive framework. For me it was challenging to understand how I could apply the concepts in this course on broader use-case scenarios. A plus side to this criticism is it teaches you a great deal about how these reactive frameworks function.

This course is great supplementary learning when paired with other sources.

results.content:
Found the first few sections of the course a good introduction to functional programming, but felt there was a sudden shift to an excessive use of libraries as soon as it was time to start building the apps. 
This really put me off and completely killed my interest in the course. It would have been much nicer to go through at least some apps being built without Ramda and the various other libraries used.

results.content: Excellent course! Just the kind of instruction that is needed for this sort of content.. providing a friendly (and concise) way of looking at these abstract concepts -- done in a methodical way with great utilization of video editing tools to highlight talking points throughout the lessons. I am enjoying this course a great deal.
